M ilan-Italy, one of 267 the worst C O V ID -19-hit E uropean cities, had a moderate reduction in N O 2 (-18% ) compared to 268 L yon-F rance. T he increase in O 3 is believed to be attributable to the complex relationships 269 among O 3 precursors and meteorological conditions. O 3 is a secondary photochemical pollutant, 270 produced by reactions of nitrogen ox ides (N O X ), including N O 2 and nitric ox ide (N O ), volatile 271 organic compounds (V O C s) and other precursors. W e hav e shown that N O 2 emissions were 272 decreased during the study period. A ny change in N O 2 emissions is accompanied with a similar 273 change in N O , as the two are emitted together. In fact, N O emissions comprise the bulk, 90-95% , 274 of N O X emissions (E PA inventory documentation). In the short term, N O can destroy ozone, 275 while in the longer term, N O is converted to N O 2 and catalyzes O 3 production. T his rate of 276 production of O 3 process is dependent on the magnitudes of N O and N O 2 in comparison with 277 V O C s and other O 3 precursors. T herefore, this increase in O 3 concentrations is mainly ex plained 278 by an unprecedented reduction in N O x emissions leading to a lower O 3 titration by N O . O zone 279 concentration is also strongly dependent on meteorological conditions, with O 3 formation 280 enhanced by higher temperatures. T hus, O 3 concentrations are generally higher in summer than 281 in spring. It is not known whether N O X emission reductions would have increased O 3 282concentrations in E urope if these reductions had occurred in summer rather than in S pring 283 in 2020(Goldberg et al., 2020). Similarly, concentrations of SO 2 and PM 2.5 were 287 35% and 6% lower, respectively, when compared against previous years. In contrast to this, 288 concentrations of CO and O 3 were, on average, 7% and 11% higher than the average 289 concentrations from 2015-2019(Figure 4). By April 2020, satellite observations of NO 2 were 290 19% lower than average while concentrations of PM 2.5 and O 3 were 3% and 15% above average.291Like Europe, these changes in ambient concentrations are likely due to lockdown measures taken 292 during mid-March across the US. The observed increase in ozone, shown inFigure 4, is slightly 293 more prominent in the US than in Europe due to the southern areas of the US observing much 294 warmer temperatures in March and April, which is favorable for ozone formation.

Europe saw the largest296 reduction in NO 2 column loading in April (18%) when compared against the base years, while 297 South America saw the smallest reduction (-0.79%) in March. The average reduction of NO 2 298 over all continents except Antarctica was about 14-15% in March and April. This is consistent 299 with the reduction in CO 2 emissions from combustion estimated by Le Quéré et al (2020) during 300 this period. While there was an overall global reduction, the magnitude of the reductions can 301 likely be attributed to restrictions placed upon each country during this period. Because COVID-302 19 did not reach South America until late February (compared with December 2019 in the US 303 and January 2020 in Europe), restrictions were not as strict during this study period when 304 compared against other continents and countries. For example, São Paulo, Brazil, is the largest 305 city in Latin America, with a population of 12,252,023 people. Similarly, a study by Venter et al., (2020) using a network of 313 >10,000 air quality stations in 34 countries found that PM2.5 and NO2 concentrations decreased 314 by about 31% and 60%, respectively. Four major cities were 330 chosen in this analysis: New York City (USA), Milan (Italy), Wuhan (China), and New Delhi 331 (India). Figure 5A shows the concentrations of pollutants in New York as a fraction of the 332 average concentration of the base period (2015-2019) on a monthly temporal scale. The monthly 333 analysis shows concentrations of PM 2.5 , NO 2 , SO 2 and CO declining (90±5%, 36±8%, 40±35%, 334 and 10±3%, respectively) in the study period. In New York, NO 2 satellite observations were 51% 335 and 28% lower, on average, in March and April 2020, respectively, when compared with the 336 baseline average column loadings for the given month from 2015-2020. In contrast, ambient 337 measurements of SO 2 show concentrations increasing by 10±10% during the period. In Milan, 338 concentrations of PM, NO 2 , CO and SO 2 all drastically declined (22±19%, 40±10%, 30±30%, 339 and 30±30%, respectively) between January and February before increasing through the end of 340 the study period (Figure 5B). In contrast, O 3 concentrations were above average (18±8%) 341 compared with previous years. In Milan, NO 2 satellite observations were 55% and 49% lower, 342 on average, in March and April 2020, respectively, when compared with the baseline average 343 column loadings for the given month from 2015-2020. The concentrations of pollutants from 344 January to April of 2020 as a fraction of the average concentration in the base period for Wuhan, 345 China, were also observed on a monthly scale (Figure 5C). On a monthly scale, the 346 concentrations of CO declined through the period, while concentrations of SO 2 and O 3 steadily 347 increased. In contrast to this, PM and NO 2 concentrations initially decreased before starting to 348 increase in March/April. In Wuhan, NO 2 satellite observations were 62%, 50% and 18% lower, 349 on average, in February, March and April 2020, respectively, when compared with the baseline 350 average column loadings for the given month from 2015-2020. The concentrations of pollutants 351 from January to April of 2020 as a fraction of the average concentration in the base period for 352 New Delhi, India, were also observed on a monthly scale (Figure 5D). The average monthly 353 concentrations of CO increased through March before dropping in April, while concentrations of 354 NO 2 , PM and O 3 all peaked in February before declining, with all pollutants, except SO 2 , at a 355 minimum in April. In New Delhi, India, NO 2 satellite observations were 24% and 54% lower, on 356 average, in March and April 2020, respectively, when compared with the baseline average 357 column loadings for the given month from 2015-2020. The reduction in CO, PM and NO 2 358 concentrations can likely be primarily attributed to the mandatory shut down of non-essential 359 personnel. Because the timings of the mandatory quarantine periods varied city to city, the 360 timelines for changes in the concentrations also vary. The increase in O 3 can be attributed to the 361 reduction of NO emissions from automobiles and industrial activities. SO 2 concentrations 364 sharply increase through the period toward the end of the study period. T he compared five-year period was used as the baseline for air quality not influenced 391 by the lockdowns provides a more robust analysis. T he purpose of the inclusion of this period is 392 two-fold: (1) to normalize the impacts of meteorological factors to the atmospheric 393 concentrations of air pollutants;(2) to narrow down the case studies to locations that have long-394 term measurements and data-series. B y means of normalizing the meteorological influences and 395narrowing down the case studies, this study attempts to corroborate a closer ex amination on the 396 lockdown effect rather than to generalize the findings by incorporating more locations with a 397shorter data coverage. M oreover, incorporating a short baseline period may result in a bias 398 inherited from prevalent meteorological conditions during that period. B y introducing a longer 399 baseline period, this bias may be minimized. Similarly, PM 2.5 concentrations in the United States were primarily 415 below average or around average for much of the US while O 3 concentrations were slightly 416 above average. 417 Ambient concentrations of each pollutant were also examined on a city-wide scale. Ambient 418 concentrations of PM 2.5 , PM 10 , NO 2 and CO in each city generally declined in association with 419 quarantine orders placed upon the states, while SO 2 and O 3 concentrations generally increased. 420 The only city that did not see an increase in O 3 concentrations through the study period, which 421 can potentially be attributed to meteorological conditions in New Delhi. These changes in the 422 concentrations of these pollutants can likely be, in part, attributed to the reductions in traffic and 423 industrial activity associated with lockdown measures taken to contain COVID-19. The increase 424 in O 3 concentrations can likely be attributed to a reduction in NO emissions, which thus reduces 425 the reaction of NO with O 3 to form NO 2 . In some regions (e.g. India and China), SO 2 426concentrations increased through the period which can likely, in part, be attributed to an increase 427 in the combustion of coal to heat houses and electricity production.

FIGREF5.text: Based on the results of this study as well as the results of Shi and Brasseur (2020), Venter et al., 429 (2020), and Bauwens et al. (2020), it is evident the lockdown orders associated with COVID-19 430 have had a profound impact on our atmospheric environment. With the reduction in industrial 431 activities and residential automobile activity, the ambient concentrations of PM, CO, NO 2 and, in 432 some cases, SO 2 were much lower than they normally are likely due to a combination of lower 433 emissions and meteorological conditions. In contrast to this, O 3 concentrations were higher than 434 normal due to the reduction in emissions from traffic. It is important to note that these changes in 435 ambient concentrations are not permanent and it is not possible at this time to determine any 436 long-term impacts of this reduction in emissions on air quality at a global, regional and urban 437 scales. However, lack of preparedness for the coronavirus only highlights the need for a long-438 term air pollution and climate change strategy requiring transitioning to clean-energy (i.e. 439 supporting renewables and energy efficiency). Additionally, this does not mean poor air quality 440 should return. It too, should be made history.
